15053.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the contextual sentence SN8.6, the form `udīrayi` is glossed as `udīriyi udīriyati (sāmaññaphalasuttaṭīkānurūpaṃ)`. This indicates that the Aorist form `udīrayi` is being interpreted here as a passive present tense verb `udīriyati`, particularly in relation to the commentary on the Sāmaññaphala Sutta. The meaning "is spoken; is uttered" is consistent with the passive voice and the root meaning of uttering or speaking. The phrase "paṭibhānaṃ udīrayi" therefore translates to "his eloquence was uttered" or "his eloquence was spoken".
15053.example_1:
saṃkhittenapi deseti,
vitthārenapi bhāsati,
sāḷikāyiva nigghoso,
paṭibhānaṃ udīrayi [udīriyi udīriyati (sāmaññaphalasuttaṭīkānurūpaṃ)].

43009.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the context of the sentence, "paramodāna" describes the knowledge ("ñāṇa") that has been "perfectly cleansed" or "purified". This suggests a state of immaculate understanding or insight.
43009.example_1: that knowledge has been perfectly cleansed:

63953.meaning_1: name of a discourse; discourse on the pure method
63953.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
The title refers to the 24th sutta of the Iddhipāda Saṃyutta (SN 51). It is called "Suddhika" because it defines the four bases of power (iddhipāda) in a "pure" or straightforward manner, without additional details found in other discourses in the same collection.

24254.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence from SN 8.2, the form 'gadhitāse' is an archaic or Vedic-style nominative plural. The term describes beings who are 'bound' or 'clinging' to their 'upadhi' (attachments/acquisitions). In this specific sense (gadhita 2), the literal meaning of being 'tied' (√gadh/grath) extends to the psychological state of greed and infatuation.
24254.example_1: People are bound to their attachments,

53314.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
The second of two suttas with this name in the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically SN 44.7 in the Abyākatasaṃyutta. In this discourse, Moggallāna explains to Vacchagotta why the Buddha does not answer speculative questions about the nature of the world and the soul, attributing the clinging to these views to a lack of understanding of the five aggregates.

10545.meaning_1: surpassing ignorance; overcoming not knowing; transcending illusion
10545.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence SN 9.2, the word appears in the ablative form avijjāsamatikkamā, meaning "through the overcoming of ignorance" or "by going beyond ignorance". It is a genitive determinate compound where avijjā (ignorance) is the object of samatikkama (overcoming).

43008.meaning_1: of the highest purity; superlatively white; exceedingly clear
43008.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence from SN 9.2, this term is a variant reading for paramavodāna or pariyodāta. It describes the superlative purity or clarity of knowledge (ñāṇa) that arises once a practitioner has overcome craving and ignorance.
43008.example_1:
chandarāgassa vinayā,
avijjāsamatikkamā,
taṃ ñāṇaṃ paramodānaṃ [pariyodātaṃ,
paramodātaṃ,
paramavodānaṃ],
kasmā pabbajitaṃ tape.

43001.meaning_1: perfectly pure; supremely purified; highest purification
43001.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the context of SN 9.2, this term is used as an adjective describing knowledge (ñāṇaṃ) that has become perfectly pure or supremely cleansed through the removal of desire and ignorance. Its synonyms in the verse variants (pariyodāta and paramodāta) emphasize the quality of being completely stainless or brilliant.
43001.example_1:
chandarāgassa vinayā,
avijjāsamatikkamā,
taṃ ñāṇaṃ paramodānaṃ [pariyodātaṃ,
paramodātaṃ,
paramavodānaṃ],
kasmā pabbajitaṃ tape.

20804.meaning_1: discourse to the monk of the Kassapa clan; name of the third sutta in the Vanasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya
20804.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
The contextual sentence SN 9.3 (Vanasaṃyutta) refers to this sutta, which describes a deity admonishing a monk of the Kassapa clan for being too involved in teaching the laity rather than his own meditation.

24931.meaning_1: wandering the rugged mountains; frequenting mountain fastnesses
24931.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the context of SN 9.3, this adjective describes a character or a thought wandering in difficult, rugged mountain terrain. The compound consists of giri (mountain), dugga (rugged, a fastness), and cara (wandering). The translation "nimrod" in the provided snippet is a figurative reference to a hunter.

907.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the context of SN 9.3, acetasa describes someone who is unthinking or lacking mental reflection, being paired with appapañña (unintelligent). Morphologically, it is an adjective formed by adding the taddhita suffix -a to the s-stem noun cetas.

19061.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence (SN 9.3), the word appears in the form "ovadaṃ", which is an archaic masculine nominative singular of the present participle "ovadanta" (equivalent to the standard "ovadanto"). It refers to a monk who is giving advice or instruction at an inappropriate time.
19061.example_1: It’s a waste of time to advise him, mendicant;

26569.meaning_1: speaking brilliantly; eloquent; gifted in speech; who speaks brilliantly
26569.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the context of SN 9.4, this term describes the Vajjiputtaka monks who were eloquent and learned. The word is an adjective (bahubbīhi) formed from the feminine kammadhāraya noun cittakathā (brilliant or variegated speech).
26569.example_1: They were so learned, such brilliant speakers!

65743.meaning_1: Vajjian region; land of the Vajjians
65743.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence from SN 9.4, the word appears in the locative singular form (vajjibhūmiyā), referring to the geographic territory of the Vajjian confederacy.
65743.example_1: and some are in the Vajjian lands.

25020.meaning_1: excessively involved in persuading laypeople; too often convincing householders
25020.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
The compound describes a monk (specifically Ven. Ananda in the SN 9.5 context) who spends a disproportionate amount of time in social interaction—convincing or instructing the laity—at the expense of his own solitary meditation practice.
25020.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando ativelaṃ gihisaññattibahulo viharati.
25020.example_1: Now at that time Ānanda was spending too much time persuading lay people.

55064.meaning_1: thicket at the root of a tree; forest thicket; jungle at the foot of a tree
55064.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the context of the Vana Saṃyutta (SN 9.5), this term refers to the dense jungle area at the base of trees, a typical place for forest-dwelling monks to practice meditation. The word gahana implies an impenetrable or thick part of the forest.
55064.example_1: “You’ve left for the jungle, the root of a tree,

44573.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence from SN 9.5, the gerund describes the action of the monk entering or going into the thicket (gahana) at the foot of a tree (rukkhamūla) for the purpose of solitary meditation.
44573.example_1: “You’ve left for the jungle, the root of a tree,

18727.meaning_1: having laid; having placed; having stored
18727.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
opiya is the gerund of opeti (equivalent to Sanskrit āvapati). I have corrected the grammar field from "upeti" to "opeti" as the word is clearly related to the act of depositing or laying (āvapati), not "going to" (upeti), which is confirmed by the provided related headword and the contextual sentence.
18727.example_1: having laid extinguishment in your heart.

28747.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence from the Vanasaṃyutta (SN 9.5), this is an imperative command to practice meditation addressed to Gotama. The form jhā is an archaic or poetic contraction of the standard imperative jhāyāhi (from the base jhāya), often used in verse for metrical purposes.
28747.example_1:
rukkhamūlagahanaṃ pasakkiya,
nibbānaṃ hadayasmiṃ opiya,
jhā gotama mā pamādo [mā ca pamādo],
kiṃ te biḷibiḷikā karissatīti.

48461.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
This is an onomatopoeic term used to describe meaningless or repetitive noise. In the context of SN 9.5, it refers to the "hullabaloo" or "gibberish" that might distract a monk from his meditation.
48461.example_1: What use is this hullabaloo to you?”

5149.meaning_1: sixth discourse in the forest collection; discourse concerning Anuruddha
5149.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
The sixth discourse in the Vanasaṃyutta (Forest Collection) of the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 9.6). In this sutta, a forest deity (devatā) addresses the Venerable Anuruddha while he is dwelling in a forest thicket among the Kosalans, encouraging him in his meditation.

58788.meaning_1: possessing every sensual pleasure; having every desire granted
58788.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence SN 9.6, this compound functions as an adjective in the locative plural (sabbakāmasamiddhisu). The translation "whose every desire is granted" reflects the sense of attainment or success (samiddhi) of all objects of desire (sabbakāma).

34022.meaning_1: divine maiden; celestial nymph; heavenly girl
34022.comment:
gemini: gemini-3-flash-preview
In the contextual sentence from SN 9.6, the deity Jālinī encourages the venerable Anuruddha to seek rebirth in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, suggesting he would "shine" among the divine maidens there.

41974.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The provided English translation for the contextual sentence ("who are attached to divine maidens”) appears to interpret "patthitā" as "attached to" rather than "desired by," which is the standard passive meaning for this past participle. Grammatically, "devakaññāhi patthitā" literally means "desired by divine maidens," where "devakaññāhi" is the instrumental agent. The `plus_case` is `+instr` to reflect this passive construction.
41974.example_1: who are attached to divine maidens.”

46776.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The contextual sentence 'natthi dāni punāvāso' (There is now no renewed existence/dwelling) strongly supports the meaning of 'staying again' or 'living once more', often in the context of rebirth or a return to a specific state.
46776.example_1: O Penelope, weaver of the web—

34025.grammar: masc loc sg of devakāya, comp
34025.meaning_1: in the host of heavenly beings; among the group of gods
34025.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The locative singular ending -smi is an attested alternative to -e or -asmiṃ for a-stem masculine nouns. The contextual sentence "devakāyasmi jālini" (there are no more abodes for me in the host of gods) clearly indicates a locative sense.
34025.example_1: there are no more abodes for me in the host of gods.

36043.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
This entry refers to the sutta (discourse) associated with the individual Nāgadatta, found in the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically SN9.7. The compound type is genitive tatpurisa, indicating "Nāgadatta's discourse".

36042.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
Nāgadatta is a proper name, meaning 'given by dragons', fitting the pattern of similar names like Devadatta ('given by gods'). In the contextual sentence, it refers to a Venerable monk residing in Kosala.
36042.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā nāgadatto kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
36042.example_1: At one time Venerable Nāgadatta was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

2380.meaning_1: wandering too long; spending an excessive amount of time
2380.meaning_lit: one who wanders beyond the proper time
2380.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The word ativelacārī is an adjective describing someone who stays out or continues an activity beyond the appropriate or usual time. In the contextual sentence divā ca āgantvā ativelacārī;, it refers to returning "too late in the day", highlighting the aspect of excessive time spent before returning. The compound ativela (excessive time) modifies cārī (wanderer/doer), implying an excessive manner or duration of wandering/acting. The compound type is Kammadhāraya as the first element adverbially qualifies the second.
2380.example_1: and returning too late in the day,

64128.meaning_1: too bold; very reckless; extremely impudent
64128.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
In the contextual sentence, "suppagabbha" describes Nāgadatta as "reckless", conveying the sense of being excessively bold or impudent.
64128.example_1: I’m afraid for Nāgadatta; he’s reckless,

16499.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The verb "upesi" is the 3rd singular aorist form of "upeti". In the contextual sentence "antakassa vasaṃ upesī”, it means "entered the sway of the terminator". The `lemma_2` field has been changed to `upeti` as per the instruction to reduce inflected verbs to their 3rd singular present tense form. The `verb`, `trans`, `plus_case`, `meaning_1`, `meaning_lit`, and `construction` fields have been completed based on Pāḷi grammatical rules and the provided contextual sentence.
16499.example_1: under the sway of the terminator!”

66467.meaning_1: falls under the power; comes under the control (of)
66467.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
This compound verb is formed by the accusative singular of `vasa` (power, control) and the verb `eti` (to go, come). It typically takes a genitive object to indicate whose power or control one falls under. The contextual sentence uses a similar verbal compound `vasaṃ upesīti`, where `upeti` is a synonym of `eti` (from `upa` + `eti`).
66467.example_1:
bhāyāmi nāgadattaṃ suppagabbhaṃ,
kulesu vinibaddhaṃ,
mā heva maccurañño balavato,
antakassa vasaṃ upesīti [vasameyyāti,
vasamesīti].

22536.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The Kulagharaṇīsutta (SN 9.8) is a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (Connected Discourses) that features a conversation between a deity and a monk regarding the virtues and duties of a noble or respectable housewife.

1416.meaning_lit: one who has attained deep involvement; deeply entered-attained
1416.compound_construction: ajjhogāḷha (pp of ajjhogāhati) + patta (pp of pāpuṇāti)
1416.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
In the contextual sentence, "ajjhogāḷhappatto" is the masculine nominative singular form, referring to the monk (bhikkhu). The meaning "too closely involved in the affairs of a certain family" highlights the negative connotation often implied by such deep involvement for a monk, suggesting inappropriate attachment or transgression of monastic rules.
1416.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu aññatarasmiṃ kule ativelaṃ ajjhogāḷhappatto viharati.
1416.example_1: Now at that time that monk had become too closely involved in the affairs of a certain family.

22535.meaning_1: mistress of the house; lady of the house
22535.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The contextual sentence describes 'kulagharaṇī' as the 'mistress of that family' whose appearance the deity takes to stir up the monk. This aligns perfectly with the primary meaning of 'mistress of the house' or 'lady of the house'. The compound `kula` (family) + `gharaṇī` (mistress of the house) forms a genitive tatpurisa, indicating 'mistress belonging to the family'.
22535.sutta_1: atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yā tasmiṃ kule kulagharaṇī, tassā vaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
22535.example_1: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for that monk, wanting what’s best for him. So, wanting to stir him up, they manifested in the appearance of the mistress of that family, approached the monk, and addressed him in verse:

21763.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The contextual sentence 'mañca tañca kimantaran”ti' translates to 'what’s going on between you and me?', directly supporting the meaning 'what's between?' or 'what's happening with?'. The phonetic change 'ṃa > ma' describes the sandhi transformation of 'kiṃ' and 'antara' to form 'kimantara'. The `plus_case` '+acc' is confirmed by the accusative pronouns 'mañca' and 'tañca' in the example.
21763.example_1: what’s going on between you and me.”

39559.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
In the contextual sentence, 'paccūhā' is the nominative plural form of 'paccūha', agreeing with 'saddā' (sounds). It means 'echoing' or 'resounding', describing the nature of the many sounds present in the context.

71482.meaning_lit: that which should be; that which ought to be
71482.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
In the contextual sentence "na tena maṅku hotabbaṃ", hotabbaṃ is used impersonally meaning "it ought not to be" or "one ought not to be", with maṅku (dismayed) as the predicate adjective and tena (by that) indicating the cause or agent. Thus, "They ought not be dismayed by that.".
71482.example_1: They ought not be dismayed by that,

57988.meaning_1: disturbed by sound; worried about noise
57988.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The contextual sentence "yo ca saddaparittāsī, If you’re startled by every little sound," confirms the meaning of being disturbed or worried by noise. The compound is a Bahubbīhi, describing an individual who is characterized by experiencing fear or disturbance due to sound.
57988.example_1: If you’re startled by every little sound,

66746.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The contextual sentence "vane vātamigo yathā; like a wind-deer in the wood," suggests a deer that is naturally found in windy environments or is swift like the wind, commonly referring to a swift-footed deer or antelope species. The compound type is Kammadhāraya as "wind" describes a characteristic of the "deer".
66746.example_1: like a wind-deer in the wood,

65741.meaning_1: the discourse about Vajjiputta; the Vajjiputta Sutta
65741.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
This entry refers to Sutta 9.9 in the Saṃyutta Nikāya, which is part of the Vanasaṃyutta. The title indicates that the discourse either features or concerns a person named Vajjiputta.

65738.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash
The headword `vajjiputtaka` is an adjective derived via the taddhita suffix `ka` from the compound `vajjiputta`. The compound `vajjiputta` (son of the Vajji) is a genitive tatpurisa compound. The contextual sentence "ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro vajjiputtako bhikkhu vesāliyaṃ viharati" shows `vajjiputtako` (masculine nominative singular) modifying `bhikkhu`, indicating a mendicant belonging to or coming from the Vajji confederacy, hence "Vajjian mendicant".
65738.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro vajjiputtako bhikkhu vesāliyaṃ viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
65738.example_1: At one time a certain Vajjian mendicant was staying near Vesālī in a certain forest grove.

36944.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, the word is in the masculine accusative singular form, modifying the sound (sadda) of musical instruments (tūriya), striking (tāḷita), and playing (vādita).
36944.example_1: tena kho pana samayena vesāliyaṃ vajjiputtako sabbaratticāro hoti. atha kho so bhikkhu vesāliyā tūriya-tāḷita-vādita-nigghosasaddaṃ sutvā paridevamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi –

31118.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, the word is part of the compound tūriya-tāḷita-vādita-nigghosasaddaṃ, referring to the sound (saddaṃ) produced by striking (tāḷita), blowing (vādita), and sounding (nigghosa) musical instruments (tūriya).
31118.example_1: tena kho pana samayena vesāliyaṃ vajjiputtako sabbaratticāro hoti. atha kho so bhikkhu vesāliyā tūriya-tāḷita-vādita-nigghosasaddaṃ sutvā paridevamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi –

32335.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, it refers to a log dumped in the forest, fulfilling the role of a wood or timber piece.
32335.example_1: like a log dumped in the forest.

17902.meaning_1: of such a kind; like this
17902.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The stem etādisik- is a taddhita derivative (with suffix -ika) of the correlative adjective etādisa ("of such a kind"). In the context of the Thig verse, it modifies rattiyā ("night") in the instrumental case (etādisikāya), functioning adverbially to mean "on a night such as this."

57244.meaning_1: sutta for rehearsal; sutta to be recited
57244.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In SN9.10, sajjhāyasuttaṃ functions as the title of a sutta. The term sajjhāya typically means "rehearsal" or "recitation." Therefore, the meaning is "the sutta for rehearsal" or "the recitation sutta." The first part, sajjhāya, may be in the vocative case (dear recitation) or an adjective modifying sutta.

36221.meaning_1: does not study; does not learn by heart; does not recite
36221.construction:
na + adhi + iya + ti
na + adhīyati
36221.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of SN 9.10, the word occurs in the line "nādhīyasi bhikkhuhi saṃvasanto". The English translation "living together with other mendicants?" suggests a context of monastic life. Although the literal meaning is "does not study/recite", the usage here likely implies "does not engage (in study/recitation)" while living with other monks, or that the monks one lives with do not study. Given the potential corruption of "saṃvasanto" (living together) or "saṃvasa" (community), the negation applies to the activity of the monks.

61905.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence sn9.10:2.2 (nādhīyasi bhikkhuhi saṃvasanto), the participle functions as an agent/participant in the action of living with the bhikkhus (instrumental plural bhikkhuhi). The English translation "living together with" captures this agentive role and the required instrumental case.
